docs.lead_paragraph: Exercise - you know you should be doing it, but something always seems to keep you from getting started. You don't have time, the weather's bad, there's no good place to work out, there's no one to watch the kids, it disrupts your day, you're too tired or, perhaps the most common and truthful excuse of them all, you hate to exercise. You're not alone. More than 60 percent of Americans get little or no exercise, despite repeated reminders about the myriad rewards of regular physical activity to body and mind.

headline.main: Persuading Potatoes To Get Off the Couches

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of getting more exercise; cites two studies reported in Journal of American Medical Association that found that benefits of exercise can be achieved simply by incorporating more movement into one's daily routine; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Contrary to previous reports, women who drink moderately -- up to one and a half alcoholic drinks a day -- may face no increased risk of developing breast cancer, according to a decades-long study of 5,000 women in Framingham, Mass. In fact, the study by researchers at Boston University School of Medicine suggests that breast cancer risk may even decline slightly as alcohol consumption rises from none to one and a half drinks a day.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Boston University School of Medicine find that breast cancer risk in women may decline slightly as alcohol consumption rises from none to one and half drinks a day (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors have found a bold new way of helping people who have had strokes recover the ability to talk and move their limbs in the first weeks and months after brain injury. Patients are given low doses of amphetamine, the common stimulant, along with intense physical therapy, a combination that appears to accelerate recovery in many people. But, doctors caution, the treatment is experimental and may not be appropriate for all stroke victims, especially elderly people with heart disease or other serious ailments. Nevertheless, it is the first effective treatment ever found for helping people recover function after the acute phase of a stroke has passed.

headline.main: New Therapy Helps Some Stroke Patients

docs.lead_paragraph: Most cases of Parkinson's disease are not caused by a genetic defect but by other factors that are probably environmental, a study of more than 17,000 twins has found. ''For the first time, today we can say that for people with Parkinson's disease diagnosed after age 50, it's most commonly caused by environmental factors,'' said Dr. Caroline M. Tanner of the Parkinson's Institute in Sunnyvale, Calif., who led the study. It was published in the most recent issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline.main: Twins Study Links Parkinson's Disease to Environment

docs.abstract: Study of more than 17,000 twins finds that most cases of Parkinson's disease are not caused by genetic defect but by other factors that are probably environmental (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Capital Y.M.C.A. Service Center in downtown Washington is a far cry from the Y's of old. It boasts two spacious fitness centers, offers little in the way of community services and does not allow children on weekdays. Members can also choose between a basic membership and the more glitzy athletic membership, which gives customers access to a second gym, laundry service and sauna. These facts are the essence of a long-standing feud between nonprofit organizations and commercial health clubs.

headline.main: Health Clubs Cry Foul as Y's Go Upscale

docs.abstract: Private health club owners complain that YMCA's, community centers, hospitals and other not-for-profit organizations can open fitness centers and pay no taxes on them while competing directly and unfairly with health clubs that pay taxes; photo of scene at YMCA fitness center in Washinton; first lawsuit embodying this complaint has been fired against YMCA in Secane, Pa; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Apple-shaped children -- those with more fat around the midsection -- have more heart disease risk factors than their pear-shaped peers, according to a study reported yesterday. Previous studies have shown that adults with more weight around their waists have higher blood pressure and lower levels of high-density lipoprotein (''good'' cholesterol) than those whose weight gravitates around the hips and thighs. But the association between body shape and cardiovascular disease risk factors had not been well studied in children and adolescents.
docs.abstract: Study finds that apple-shaped children--those with more fat around mid-section--have more heart disease risk factors than their pear-shaped peers, those whose weight gravitates arond hips and thighs (S)
